slides.title: Code Generation
slides.ocrText: Code Generation

slides.title: Code generation (1 of 2)
slides.ocrText:
Code generation (1 of 2) G

• Acode generator processes a Guidewire resource defined in XML format (such as
PCF file, entities, typelists, etc.) and produces a Gosu or Java class

• In Studio, code generators process these resources and produce Gosu and Java
classes

* The generated classes are explicit and can be debugged
EAlasperson.eti

FAasperson.etx

Hava (configura’

slides.title: Code generation (2 of 2)
slides.originalNotes:
Code generation (2 of 2)
Note: You can learn more about .eti, -etx, and .java files in the product documentation.
slides.notes:
Code generation (2 of 2)
Note: You can learn more about .eti, -etx, and .java files in the product documentation.
slides.ocrText:
Code generation (2 of 2)

* Two types
* Incremental code generators process one or more changed resource files in isolation
• Bulk code generators process a set of resources as a whole, therefore they take longer

• Incremental code generation is not an option for all resource types

slides.title: Incremental vs Bulk code
slides.originalNotes:
Incremental vs Bulk code generators
Note: For properties that represent arrays of entities in the Guidewire data model, there arespecial rules that govern the behavior of XML output For details of the Incremental option, see "Generating XML Using an XML Model" in the product documentation.

slides.title: Output of code
slides.originalNotes:
Output of code generation
All generated resources are in the configuration\generated folder. The code generation of a PCF file results in the following: The .gs file is a Gosu class that represents the PCF type The .pcfc is a binary file that describes the PCF file for the new PCF runtime The Experssion.gs is a Gosu class that contains all container and widget expressions The code generation of an entity results in the following: A .java class representing the entity
slides.notes:
Output of code generation

slides.title: UI Debug Options
slides.ocrText: UI Debug Options

slides.title: Breakpoints
slides.originalNotes:
Brea kpoints
You can set a breakpoint by clicking in the gutter for the given line in the editor. To hit breakpoints, you must run the application in a debug 'server’ process. When the Debug 'Server' process hits a breakpoint in Gosu code, the debugger suspends the normal execution of code until you resume it. When you resume the debugger, code executes as normal until the debugger hits another breakpoint. Because you can step through lines, you normally need only one breakpoint for each section of code you want to investigate.
slides.notes:
Brea kpoints
You can set a breakpoint by clicking in the gutter for the given line in the editor. To hit breakpoints, you must run the application in a debug 'server’ process. When the Debug 'Server' process hits a breakpoint in Gosu code, the debugger suspends the normal execution of code until you resume it. When you resume the debugger, code executes as normal until the debugger hits another breakpoint. Because you can step through lines, you normally need only one breakpoint for each section of code you want to investigate.
slides.ocrText:
Breakpoints G&G

• Abreakpoint indicates a place where you want to suspend the execution of Gosu
or Java code

• When breakpoint is hit
* Studio suspends code execution
« File with breakpoint opens in Studio
• Breakpoint line highlighted in blue
* Debug tool window opens
« You can debug
• Plain old Gosu and Java resources, such as Gosu Rules, Enhancements, Classes

* Generated Gosu and Java classes produced by the code generators

slides.title: Main debugging tools
slides.originalNotes:
Main debugging tools
Debug toolbar has buttons to perform the following actions:

Restart the Debug Process

Resume execution

Stop the Debug Process

View breakpoints

Mute breakpoints

Stepping toolbar has buttons to perform the following actions:

Step over

Step into

Step out

The Frames pane enables you to gain access to the list of threads of your application, export to a text file and customize thread presentation- For each thread, you can view the stack frame, examine frames, navigate between frames, and automatically jump to a frame's source code in the editor. You can select a thread via the thread selector drop-down list on top of the pane. The status and type of a thread is indicated by a special icon and a textual note next to the thread’s name.
The Variables pane enables you to examine the values stored in the objects of your application. When a stack frame is selected in the Frames pane, the Variables pane displays all data within its scope (method parameters, local and instance variables). In this pane, you can set labels for objects, inspect objects evaluate expressions, add variables to watches and more.
In the Watches pane you can evaluate any number of variables or expressions in the context of the current stack frame. The values are updated with each step through the application and become visible every time the application is suspended- Watch expressions are always evaluated in the context of a stack frame that is currently inspected in the Frames pane. If an expression cannot be evaluated, it is displayed with a question mark.

slides.title: Demonstration
slides.ocrText: Demonstration

slides.title: Review before the demo: PCF methods
slides.originalNotes:
Review before the demo: PCF methods
A PCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file and executes some logic tied to that PCF file.
slides.notes:
Review before the demo: PCF methods
A PCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file and executes some logic tied to that PCF file.
slides.ocrText:
Review before the demo: PCF methods G&G

• APCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file
* ...iS local (private) in the PCF file that defines it (not even referenced files can access it)

* ...cannot be debugged at the place of definition (you have to open the generated
<PCFFileName>Expressions.gs file after code generation, locate the method and put a
breakpoint there)

* ...is called from a widget property (e.g.: action, value, available, editable, etc.)

* PCF methods are defined on the Code tab of the main PCF Element — container
or location — and have direct access to the root object(s)

• The logic the function implements is typically tied to one or more widgets in that
PCF file, and it is not needed anywhere else. For example:

* determining the label (View or View/Edit) for a button
* determining if a TextInput widget is editable or not editable
* executing some initialization logic after navigating to a location

_- — Name atleast one difference between incremental and bulk code
Y generation.
MS SS

questionData.question: Name atleast one difference between incremental and bulk code
questionData.answer: Y generation. Possible answers: * incremental code generator can process a single file, while bulk code generator processes a set of files • incremental code generation is not supported for every resource type bulk code generation can be started from the CodeGen menu or during project I * incremental code generation can be started on save or during project make while ' rebuild

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
_- — What is a PCF method? How can you debug a PCF method?
•
•
MS SS

questionData.question: What is a PCF method? How can you debug a PCF method?
questionData.answer: OO” APCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file and executes some logic tied to that particular PCF file. You can open the <PCFFileName>Expressions.gs file, find the function and click on the gutter area at the desired line to set a breakpoint.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
- — What is a PCF method? How can you debug a PCF method?
•
oO” APCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file and executes
some logic tied to that particular PCF file. You can open the
<PCFFileName>Expressions.gs file, find the function and click on the gutter area at
the desired line to set a breakpoint.
